abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Second Technical
            Assistance Project for Pakistan was successful. The project
            achieved its overall objectives, its impact has been
            significant, and both the Bank and Borrower performed
            satisfactorily. Several lessons can be learned from this
            project. First, the Bank's monitoring and progress
            report requirements should be simplified and made less time
            consuming. Second, if the Bank is to be involved with the
            functioning of the TA, additional staff weeks should be
            devoted for supervision of the TA credit both at the RMP and
            in Washington. Third, a simplified set of procedures for
            subprojects needs to be developed, particularly to ensure
            that routine administrative matters do not need the review
            and approval of a relatively large number of entities.
            Fourth, the project director of TAPC should have greater
            authority vested in him to decide on most matters relating
            to the award of studies, disbursements, and other
            administrative matters. Fifth, for each subproject, one
            organization should be invited to take the prime technical
            responsibility for the product. Lastly, commitment by the
            Government to the concept and objectives of the project is
            essential for effective functioning of the project.
